div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday until 10th October and thereafter every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convery passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is 9 pounds to Brindisi.
The combined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to 22.9.11 pounds Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
After 10 October the express-steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
For all further information apply to the company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1905. Dr. BARNARDO.
div.p: This morning's telegraphic news tells us of the passing away of one of England’s, or rather Ireland’s, most remarkable sons. Thomas John Bamardo, F.R.C.S., Edinburgh, whose philanthropic efforts on behalf of the waifs and strays, not only of London, but of many of the large cities of the United Kingdom, are known the wide world over, was born in 1845, and completed his 60th year only a month or taro since. Whilst a student at the London Hos pital in 1866, where he was studying, preparatory to mission work in China, his attention became directed to the terribly neglected state of the homeless boys in the East End of London. So pitiable were their tales, that it was some time before be could realise that he was not being deceived, but the more he enquired into the truth of their stories, the more did he find that the actualities were even worse than the boys’ statements. Under their guidance he explored a wilderness of old sheds, tumble-down outhouses and wreckage near Houndsditch and Petticoat-lane by night Here in one place he saw before him eleven poor boys from 9 to 18 yean of age, sleeping in all postures, clad in their rags, and exposed under the open sky to wind and rain. Those who know what this means in London, will readily believe the doctor when he says that the eight followed him and haunted him, causing him to reflect on the hideous actualities and the seamy side of modem civilisation, and rousing him to action. Possessed of indomitable energy, full of a sympathy that has never weakened, and fired with an enthusiasm that has never failed, spite of great physical weakness at times, Dr. Barnardo gave up his contemplated missionary life abroad, and devoted himself to home mission work among the waifs and stray of London, and no more convincing evidence of the wonderful gifts he possessed of organisation, persuasion, and intuition could possibly be given, than a bare recital of the list of the various institutions established by him, all endowed with a vitality that astonishes the visitor; and even at the present time increasing in number. The bare statement in the Annual Report for 1903, that 12,305 applications were received, and admission granted in 4,078 cases, gives no idea of the true meaning of the figures or of their diverse character, and it is only an intimate acquaintance with the working of the various homes and agencies, that at all enables one to form an idea of the magnitude of the work, and the enormous responsibility that rested upon the shoulders of their now deceased founder and director.

Dr. Barnardo was, undoubtedly, the chosen instrument for carrying out a work of incal-culable benefit to the world at large. The impression largely prevails that his work was confined to the helping of waif and destitute children only. These came first undoubtedly, but of the many poor children that owe their chances in life to him, many have been well and tenderly brought-up, have known more of a parent’s love than the children of wealthy parents in fashionable life whose one object is to live a life of pleasure, but, from adverse circumstances of all kinds, have become destitute. The Stepney headquarters bear in letters of gold, the following motto, “No destitute child ever refused admission,” and whatever might be the cause of the destitution the help was given, and in very many oases was not confined to the children themselves. The ramifications of this vast enterprise were enormous, and so well and thoroughly has the work been done by the various heads of departments that there is little or no fear of any disorganisation occurring through the lamented decease of the head of the institutions. Dr. Barnardo was not the man to leave things to chance. For some yean he has been warned of the inevitable result of continued work at high pressure, and tour years ago he was plainly told that he must give up work or die. But rest to a man of his temperament was simply impossible. He has gone to Nauheim every summer for treatment of the heart disease from which he suffered, only to return to work, lecture, preach, visit branch establishments, and in his spare time consider the huge mass of correspondence placed before him by his secretaries, work that frequently, even of late, occupied him till the small hours of the morning. The end has come at last, and it will not be at all surprising to those who knew Dr. Barnardo, to learn that it came suddenly, and that he died in fall harness. We regret that within the limits of this article it is impossible to give more than the hasty and imperfect sketch we have written respecting this truly remarkable man. Hie work has been monumental, and hie memory will be enshrined in the hearts of hundreds of thousands—indeed we may say millions—of those whom in one way or another he has benefited. To those who have come into personal relations with him, and knew the man himself, the loss seems irreparable, and we feel it will be long ere we shall look upon hie like again.

div.head: SCANDINAVIAN CRISIS.
HOPES OF SETTLEMENT.
div.p: Karlstad, September 20. The Swedo-Norwegian conference continues. While the main question, regarding the demolition CD the Norwegian fortresses and the eventual reference to arbitration of certain other questions, are virtually agreed upon, other knotty points are still unsettled, but it is believed that they will be adjusted satisfactorily. Meanwhile troops are kept in the neighbourhood of the frontiers. (Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
HITCH IN NEGOTIATIONS.
div.p: Paris, September 20. It is stated here that there is a hitch in the negotiations with regard to Morocco, due to the French anxiety for a precise definition of their special rights for policing the frontier. An authoritative Gorman statement declares that further serious difference is impossible. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN SOCIALISTIC CONGRESS.
THE GOVERNMENT AND MOROCCO.
div.p: Jena, September 20. The Socialistic Congress has refused to censure the attitude of the Government with regards to Parliament’s action concerning Morocco. (Havas)

div.head: GERMANY CONVOY CAPTURED.
SURPRISED BY HOTTENTOTS.
div.p: Cape Town, September 20. The Hottentots have captured a German convoy near Kietmanshoep. The escort was surprised and practically annihilated. A thousand cattle, 122 waggons, some of which were laden with ammunition, and a number of rifles were captured. (Reuter)

div.head: ITALY AND THE MULLAH.
RAIDS OF MIJERTAIN TRIBES.
div.p: Rome, September 20. Advices from Somaliland state that the Mullah has complained to Italy of the raids of certain Mijertain tribes in the Italian sphere. The attempt of the Italian warships to arrange a settlement through the Sultan of the Mijer- tains has failed. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN FREEDOM.
UKASE TO BE GRANTED.
div.p: London, September 20. The “Times” learns from St. Petersburg that an ukase granting freedom of meeting, of Speech, and of the press, and the immunity from arbitrary arrest, will be promulgated as soon as the measures can be drafted. (Reuter)

div.head: EAST-ASIATIC SERVICE
RUSSIAN VOLUNTEER FLEET DELAYS.
div.p: Odessa, September 20. The departure of the Volunteer steamers and others bound for Vladivostok has been deferred, pending the abrogation of Japan's right of capture. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA’S NAVY.
div.p: London, September 20. The “Daily News” states that a Russian Government agent in London is negotiating for the construction of the whole new navy in Great Britain. (Reuter)

div.head: GREECE AND ROUMANIA.
div.p: Athens, September 20. The Hellenic Minister at Bucharest and the Roumanian Minister at Athens have gone on leave without being replaced. (Havas)

div.head: M. WITTE VISITS M. LOUBET.
div.p: Paris, September 20. M. Witte has gone to Valencia to visit M. Loubet. (Havas)

div.head: DEATH OF DR. BARNARDO.
div.p: London, September 20. The philanthropist Dr. T. T. Banardo has died. (Reuter)

div.p: Yesterday’s plague bulletin reporta one death in hospital at Alexandria.

div.head: Sale of Land
div.p: We are informed that Dr. Varenhorst Pasha has sold a large site at Ramleh to the Egyptian Trust and Investment Company.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Bonlac district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 23 rd inst will bo poisoned by the police.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 18th inst, 8 of which were British, 1 German, 1 French. The day’s receipts were frs. 328,966 16, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 5,055,79°.80.

div.head: The Railways Administration
div.p: As a result of the public competitive examination held by the Railways Administration MM. Ugo Rossetto and Emile Arian have been appointed assistant engineers, the former at Embabeh and the latter at Alexandria.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: Wo are asked to announce that those who reserve seats for dinner at the San Stefano Casino on Saturday will be admitted to the subscribers’ grand ball. Subscribers are asked to note that no invitations will be issued, but that their subscription tickets will gain admittance for them.

div.head: Sudan Government Transfers
div.p: El Bim-bashi A.A.C. Taylor, junior inspector of the Bahr el Ghazal province has been transferred to a similar post in the Berber province ; El Bimbashi H.W. Channer, 3rd Battalion transferred to the Sudan Government, has been appointed junior inspector of the Bahr el Ghazal province, has been retransferred to the Army ; Mr. W.E Drommond Hay, deputy-inspector in the Finance Department has been appointed junior inspector therein.

div.head: Ministry of Finance
div.p: The following modifications, to date from the 1st October, will take place in the duties of the inspectors and sub inspectors consequent on the absence on leave of Mr. Etherington Smith and Burnett Stuart: —Inspector Haines will bo in charge of Menoufieh, Galioubieh and Dakahlieh provinces, inspector Mohamed Effendi Housny will be in charge of the Mudiriehs of Keneh, Guirgeh and Assouan and inspector Dallin will be in charge of the Gharbieh and Bahera provinces.

div.head: For the Calabrian Sufferers
div.p: We would once more appeal to our Alexandria readers to support a benefit performance for the relief of the victims of the Calabrian earthquake. To-morrow night the Società Filodrammatica la Margherita will hold a ''soirée de gala” at the Eden Theatre for the benefit of the sufferers, and have arranged a programme which cannot fail to please any audience. This society Will present the Italian comedy Infidele, which will be followed by the farce II Cuoco ed il Segretario, and the Armenian band will play selections during the intervals.

div.head: Société Réunion des Familles
div.p: A grand fête will be given by the Société Réunion des Families at the Mex Casino on Saturday, commencing at 9.30 p.m. The programme will include a ball, and a vocal and instrumental concert in which Mlles. G. Capozzi and M. Tortella, and MM. G. Sacco, J. Andresti, andE. Chaloub will take part. The Armenian band will provide the music for the dances, of which no fewer than twenty-one appear on the programme, including polkas, waltzes, lancers, barn-door dance, pas des patineurs, a moulinet du pas de quatre, a galop, and the inevitable cake-walk. At 1 a.m. there will be a grand quadrille, as an adieu to the Mex season, and at 2 a.m. a lottery for thirty prizes will be drawn. The casino will be brilliantly illuminated à la Vénitienne, and there will also be a firework display. The entertainment will be under the patronage of Baron E. Acton, consul-general for Italy, and the proceeds of the lottery will be given to the relief fund for the victims of the Calabrian earthquake, two circumstances which cannot fail to attract large crowds.

We have pleasure in calling the attention of our readers to the splendid preparation of Messrs. Allen and Hanburys, Ltd., the celebrat-ed London chemists, which is being offered for sale under the title of "Allenburys’ Diet.” It would seem to be specially suitable for our climate, where the best of milk is not always obtainable. We are informed that Messrs. Allenburys’ Diet is a complete food in itself for invalids, convalescents, and the aged. It is very palatable, easily prepared, and when. taken before bed-time will be found to induce sleep. Allenburys’ Diet can be carried to advantage by tourists travelling at home or abroad. It is made in a minute, and is very easy of assimilation. [Advt.]

We beg to call our readers’ attention to “Tozer’s Handbook of Foreign Consular and Customs Regulations,” (Wm. Agnew, 24 Mark Line, E.C. 1s/- net). Merchants and Shippers will find this a very useful addition to their reference library. It contains all the Consular and Customs regulations for various ports throughout the world. [Advt.]

div.head: THE SUCRERIES. FEATURES OF CONCORDAT.
div.p: A reprieve saves a prisoner from being hanged, it does not necessarily carry with it an order of his instant release from gaol. Such is the character of the concordat préventif ; it staves off a sudden and reverberating financial crash, but it may only delay a compulsory liquidation. In the case of the Sucreries, we hope for the sake of the country that the respite will enable the company to reorganise and recover, but while we recognise this pleasant possibility, we cannot shut our eyes to the fact that nothing in the decision of the, Cairo Mixed Court can be taken as a guarantee that the compulsory winding-up of the company will not eventually become necessary. Article 206 (new) of the Mixed Code gives the terms on which a person or corporation is allowed to enjoy the benefit of the concordat préventif. Its chief features are these. The appointment by the tribunal of one of its members, the “juge commissaire” who takes and goes through the debtor’s books and finds his exact financial situation, decides under what conditions if any, the debtor can continue to do business, calls a meeting of the creditors, reads them a report on the situation, on the question of the debtor’s good faith and his proposals.
Once the juge commissaire is appointed the debtor ceases payments by right.

The names of the administrators under the concordat suggested by Maitre Carton de Wiart have been formally accepted by the Court. M. Debourg, we understand, will sign for his colleagues, Sir Elwin Palmer and Harari Pasha, during their absence.

div.head: NEW HOTELS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Besides the National and the New Khedi-vial, the former in the Sharia Soliman Pasha, and the latter in the Sharia Bab-el-Hadid, both of which are announced to open on the 1st November, we learn that a well-known Swiss group are in treaty for the purchase of the Khedivah-Mother’s palace in the Kasr-el-Donbara quarter, for the propose of transforming it into a first-class hotel, whilst the representative of another syndicate just arrived in Cairo has been making enquiries for acquiring property in the Opera Square, also with the intention of erecting a large up-to-date hotel with a splendid arcade of shops underneath. We shall publish fuller details of both projects as soon as the negotiations now in progress are completed.

div.head: A DRAMA OF THE DESERT.
div.p: In our issue of the 13st instant we mentioned that advice bad been received from Assiout by the Ministry of the Interior that two camel-men, accompanied by a policeman, who had left there the previous week, having in their charge some money for the pay of the police at the Oasis, bad been murdered, and that the policeman who returned to Assiout with the news was wounded in the bead. As the money was found intact it was at once seen that the motive for the crime could not have been robbery. An enquiry was at once instituted by the local Parquet and the mamour of the district, while a force of police was sent in search of the murderers who, the wounded policeman averred, were brigands. As no tracks could be found near the spot where the murders had been committed suspicion was aroused,and the policeman was suspected of having been guilty of the deed himself. It now appears that the latter was accompanied by his wife, and three traders also went with the caravan.

From the evidence of the latter it now transpires that it was the policeman himself who shot the camelman, (not two as originally reported), in consequence of having discovered an intrigue between him and the woman. On hearing the report of a gun one of the traders rushed out of his tent to discover the cause, and was himself also shot dead. The medical man who examined the wounded policeman was of opinion that the wounds he bore in the head were self inflicted, and such turns out to be the case. This man, who is now in hospital, has been placed under arrest, and will be tried for the murders as soon as he is sufficiently recovered.

div.head: A PETITION.
div.p: An energetic young official, while on inspection in the Delta recently, received the following pathetic appeal:—

Sir,—I have the honour to inform you that as I am a poor, have a large family, working alone without any help, I ask you kindly to forgive me and send a permission to the Police Office by which it forgives me also, I sent this hoping that your honesty and pardon are well known over the globes and at last I call out “God save our Inspector.”
I am your obedient servant,
M.A.E A BUTCHER.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT LTD.
div.p: Mr. H. J. L. Beadnell, F. G. S., F. R. G. S., Manager in the Oases and Geological Expert, is now en route to Egypt to take up his appointment.

div.head: NILE VALLEY.
div.p: The “Financier” announces on September 13 that the manager cables corrected returns from the battery for August;—Total amount crushed-, 405 tons, yielding 865 oz of gold. Have struck rich ore 200 ft level north ; extent at present unknown.—Office note. :—A cable has been sent to the manager requesting full information as to the rich chute mentioned in the above cable.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
NIGHT NAVIGATION IN THE CANAL
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Port Said, Tuesday.

Night navigation is now permitted, subject to certain conditions as to the beams of vessels and their power, though it is at their captain’s own risk. The Bibby line Lancashire was, I believe, the first ship to avail herself of the permission, and she arrived here safely late on Monday night.

Great interest is felt here in the coming of the members of the commission, some are to arrive to-morrow, but they will await the arrival of the “Chef du Transit” who comes on the M.M.Salazie. Rumours and wild stories are rife in the town regarding the various, proposals that have been made about the unfortunate Chatham, but I think I can safely say, that nothing is as yet decided nor will anything be until the gentlemen, whose arrival is so anxiously looked for, have carefully gone into the matter themselves.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: H.M.S. Sirius, the second-class cruiser which is expected at Suez to-morrow, is to transit the Canal at once, provided she does not receive orders there to undertake the investigation and punishment of the offenders in the recent Red Sea piracies. It is currently reported here that her captain is to return south and go into this matter at once.
The Sirius is a vessel of 3,600 tons displacement, having a speed of 19.75 knots and is armed with eight heavy guns.
The Terrible, Powerful and Renown are expected here in a short time, but doubt is expressed as to their ability to pass the Chatham, they all being of immense proportions.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF EXPLOSIVE EXPERTS.
div.p: Wednesday.

Messrs. Harris, Thomson and Cunningham experts of Nobell’s factory, together with M. Coullant and the various chiefs of the Suez Canal Company, arrived by the Brindisi mail this morning, and proceeded to the wreck of the Chatham, where lengthy deliberations were held, the results of which are unknown.

div.head: NOTABLE PASSENGERS,
div.p: The S.S. Tebe which arrived here yesterday morning had on board Marquis de Sangui-lians, Prof. Bosco, Conte Deciani, and various other members of a colonial Congress which proceeds to Asmara, close to Masawa. They dined with Conte Mancinelli Scotti at the Eastern Exchange, and proceeded through the Canal in the afternoon.

div.head: GALA PERFORMANCE AT ELDORADO.
div.p: In connection with the recent subscriptions which have been raised in aid of the sufferers from the Calabrian earthquakes, a gala perfor mance has been arranged for to night at the. Eldorado Theatre. Various members of the Consular staff here have formed themselves into a committee. The whole of the audi-torum of the theatre has been taken up and many subscriptions have been collected, among which the Comité de Bienfaisance has subscribed frs. 150.

div.head: ITALIAN NATIONAL FETE.
div.p: The fete in honor of the unification of Italy which was held last night at the Alhambra Theatre was a great success. Baron Acton and most of the principal members of the Italian Colony were present, and the audience was most patriotic. After the opening of the fete with the National hymn, which was loudly applauded, an eloquent speech by Mr. Zucchi arroused the enthusiasm of all present The pupils of the Conservatoire then gave a pretty rendering of an air by M. Colella, and then came the delightful comedy Nessuno va al campo and other historical pieces and recitations. The fireworks and, illuminations were capital, the charity bazaar and its lottery for the victims of the Calabrian Earthquake a great financial success, and the Khedive’s military hand with that of the Greeek Phil harmonic Society as well as the orchestra ably directed by Professor Gianni Galetti, were greatly appreciated. A vocal and instrumental concert with selections from La Poupee, Mascotte, Tosca, etc., and the performances of a conjuror-illusionist, finished the evening very pleasantly.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Saturday afternoon, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Khedivial mail steamship Assouan will leave Alexandria at 4 p m. on Sunday and Port Said at 4 p.m, on Monday for Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnacs, Limassol, Caiffa and Jaffa.
The M.M. Niger which left Alexandria on the 15th inst. arrived at Marseilles yesterday morning.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SILVER CURRENCY,
div.p: To THE Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—With reference, to your article of the 21st ult., your leader writer appears to have so misunderstood some of the suggestions made by Mr. Roussin as to the rules to be followed in calculating the tature currency needs of Egypt, that I should like to be allowed to criticise the critique.

The regulation of a token currency is a. comparatively simple matter, and does not give rise to the divergent theories that exist, for instance, in the case of paper currency. This is because a token currency regulates itself, the rôle of the Government being confined in ordinary circumstances to the replenishment of its stock when it is getting low, as is done, for instance, in England.

Something more than this is necessary in Egypt, because if the government waited till its holding began to get low, the new supplies could not be minted in time to meet the the demand. This makes itself felt at one season of the year only, i.e. during the cotton season in October, and November, while the silver takes three months to arrive from date of order. The instructions, to the Mint must therefore be given not later than July, supposing that it is necessary to make fresh provision.

In July and August the Government hold ing reaches its maximum (i e. the. circulation reaches its minimum) so instead of ordering new supplies, when stock is running, low, the somewhat paradoxical rule of ordering that just at the moment when there is most in band has to be adopted.
The data available for determining the amount to be ordered are as follows :

1. The demand for extra coin for the cotton crop includes and greatly exceeds the amount required to inorease the permanent circulation. The public takes what it wants for the cotton crop, retains what it necessary for increase in circulation owing to growth of population, etc., and returns the rest, when the marketing of the crop is practically over, into the hands of the Government. Thus last winter the public took out LE 360.000 in silver, of which the Government received book L.E. 200.000 daring the spring and summer of this year, the balance of LE 160.000 being retained as the permanent addition to the circulation. Hence it is obvious that there is not the slightest necessity to consider any of the points detailed by your leader-writer. The Government by providing for the cotton crop and for that alone, provides ipso facto much more than enough for all other contingencies.

2. The figures for past seasons show that the demand for the crop varies roughly according to its price, its quantity and the rapid-ity with which it is brought to market, But at the time it is necessary to order coin, none of, these factors can be foretold with any pretention to accuracy, and “keeping in touch with banks and markets” is of very little help. Therefore the only safe course is to presuppose a crop of maximum quantity at a very high price, and provide for that always.

3. To do this it becomes imperative to fix the minimum, corresponding with the above-mentioned contingency, below which the Government reserve at the opening of the cotton season most not be allowed to descend. The experience of past years shows that even in season of record crop and prices, the expansion. in the winter circulation has never-reached £400,000. That amount has there fore been chosen as the irreducible minimum the Government must have in band. This rule is not a fixed one, since it does not prevent the Government from providing any amount over the minimum which it may deem advisable.
Had this policy been initiated earlier, there would have been no impediment to the automatic self regulation of the currency, and no scarcity would have occured.—I am, Sir, etc. Fiscal.
London, September 12.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From our Financial CORRESPONDENT.
London. September 15th

During the latter part of the week the Stock Exchange has been occupied with the fort-nightly settlement, which has been an unusually heavy one, owing to the large increase in business which is now taking, place. The directors of the Bank of England decided on Thursday last to make no change in the Bank rate. Pending their decision, prices were heavy, but as soon as it was known that they had made no alteration, buoyancy all round was the order of the day. The Bank returns show that notwithstanding the large withdrawals of gold, the reserve had only fallen ₤189,000 owing to the reflux of coin and notes from circulation here; and this now stands at. £24,506,000. There is still a feeing that the demand for gold for Egypt and South America must increase, and consequently it is thought probable that a higher rate will prevail in the autumn ; even a 4% rate should not be detrimental, as the signs of improvement in trade throughout the country are becoming more evident every day. Consols, which were as low as 895/8 rose to 8913/16 , and close to day at the latter price. In the foreign market, Japanese bonds were firmer on a good demand, the First Four-and-a-half percent rising 1/4 to 947/8 and the Second 1/8 to 33/4 premium. They leave off at 943/4 and 33/4 premium respectively Russians remain unchanged, with the exception of a nominal rise of 11/3 in the Fives, Home Rails show little change on since last week, with the exception that Southern stocks have advanced slightly. The American market has been active with a reaction in prices which is considered only natural after the recent advances. Reports from the United States are most optimistic both as regards the condition of the crops and the trade outlook. Consequently higher prices are looked for all round during the winter months.

In the Egyptian section there has been some good buying of the shares of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank. The company, it is stated, has had an exceedingly profitable year, National Banks are firm at 273/4 and Agricultural Banks maintain their prices at 14 5/8. A new franco-Egyptian Bank has been formed under English law, with a capital of £500,000 in £5 shares. The whole this amount has been placed and the £5 are now quoted on the Paris Bourse at 61/4. This bank is con-nected with the Credit Mobilier in Paris and the Credito Mobiliare in Italy. which was current in the early park of the week that Sir Ernest Cassel, was interested in the promotion with the idea of assisting the reconstruction of the Societe des Sucreries et Raffinerie d’Egypte is quite incorrect.

Now that most of the parties interested in the above concern are in Cairo you will proba-bly be obtaining earlier information as to the course of events in connection with the ********** of this company ; the understanding here, however, is that it will be granted the benefit of the concordat preventif. The shares of the Daira Sugar Company are quoted today at 43/4.

In the mining section the continued interest in Rhodesian shares has had a good effect on the market generally, and if this continues we shall see higher prices in almost all sections Nile Valle, to which we called attention when they stood, at 15/— have been as high 13/8 with good-buying, due to a belief in the satisfactory settlement of the Robinson interest and also to the report from the manager that a good crushing of 405 tons yielded 365 ounces of gold. The Egyptian Mines Exploration group are firm as the result of the development in the Semna mine of the Fatira Company particulars of which appear elsewhere.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: Le Délégation Municipale fl’eat réanie le 19 Septembre 1905 à 5 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents : MM. Ahmed Bey Eyoub, L. Escof-fier, Dr Schiess, E. 8tro8s, G. Zsrvadaobi, mena bres, A Wilner, secrétaire p. i.

Snr rapport, en date du 18 Septembre 1905, de M. Easton Cornisch, d’accord aveo l’Iogé nienr en Chef de la Municipalité, la Délégation adjoge à M. D. J. Steward et Cie Ltd. la fourniture de tuyaux en fonte pour la canalisation d’eau filtrée h Ramleh au prix de Lst. 5-7-6, par tonne, les trois dimensions de tuyaux do 18, 15 et 12 pouœs et Lst. 12-15-0 la tODno pour les acoe?8oires.
Les quantités k livrer sont approximativement de 3 350 m. pour les tuyaux de 18 poncep, de 1,400 m. pour les tuyaux de 15 pouoos et de 3,700 pour les tuyaux de 12 pouces.

Communication est donnée des propositions faites par l’Administration des Chemins de fer de l’Etat et par la Cie du Gai pour l’éclairage des ponts du Canal Mahmoudieh pendant leur ouverture qui s’effectuera de nuit

S'arrêtant aux offres de la Cie du Gsz, la Délégation serait disposée à prendre bos propositions en considération, mais, avant de se prononcer, elle prie oette compagnie de lui fournir certains détails.

A l'occasion de l’établissement d’une canalisation d’eau filtrée pour Ramleh, la Délégation charge l’Inspecteur Sanitaire devoir quelles mesures il y aurait lieu de prendre eu vue de généraliser l’usage de l’eau filtrée parmi la population.
Une réglementation devra être élaborée k oet effet.

Les crédits prévus pour le dallage de diverses ruelles étant épuisés, la Délégation est d’avis d’ajourner jusqu’à l’année prochaine le dallage en vieilles dalles des raes Medawara,Sidi Khadr, Sidi Naima, Zawiet Kada, Mawlai Mohamed, Sidi Abdel Fath et autres.
Ces routes seront confectionnées les premières au commencement de l’exeroioe prochain.

La Délégation proposera à la Commission Manicipale l’ouverture de 2 orédits supplé mentaires de 50 L.E pour frais de déplacement du Service des Recettes et de L.E. 50 pour l’arrosage de la route de Montazah.
La séance a été levée à 6 b. 1/2 p.m.
Une dépêche arrivée hier après-midi nous apprend la mort de M. F. Ruhland, juge français au Tribunal Mixte d’Alexandrie, survenue à la suite d’une oongestion cérébrale.

M. F. Ruhland, qui était d’origine alsacienne, occupait il y a qatre ans à peine, le poste de conseiller à la Cour d’Appel de Paris. Il vint à Alexandrie remplacer M. F. de Longohamp^, qui était appelé lui-même à le remplacer à Paris.

D’une grande affabilité, d’un commerce agréable et facile, M. F. Ruhland était uni* versellement estimé pour sa science juridique et recherché en société pour sa gaieté et son entrain. Il sera vivement regretté ici, où il ne comptait que des amis.
Jeudi dernier a été publié l’aocord international pour la répression de la traite des blanches.

Tous les Etats de l’Europe, à l’exception de la Turquie, de la Grèce et des Etats balkaniques, s’engagent à faire surveiller, spécialement dans les gares de ohemins de fer et les ports d’embarquement et d’esoale, les personnes fai sant la traite des blanches. Us s’engagent égale ment, autant que possible, à renvoyer dans leurs pays d’origine les femmes et les jeunes filles destinées k la prostitution, si elles le désirent ou si des personnes ayant autorité snr elles les réclament. Ils s’engagent en outre, k exercer, dans les limites légales, une surveillance sur les agenoes s’oooupant de trouver un emploi à l’étranger pour les femmes et les jeunes filles.

div.head: Union Artistique Française
div.p: Messieurs, Nous avons l’honneur de vous convoquer k l’Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire qui se tiendra dans notre local sis rue Stamboul N° 8 (1er étage) le mardi, 26 courut, k 8 h. 1/2 du soir.
Noas espérons que vous ne manquerez pas k cette réunion qui a pour objet la leoture et l’approbation des Statuts et diverses autres questions intéressant les Sociétaires.

A ce sujet, noua vous rappelons que le dit local est ouvert tous les jours aux Membres Actifs de 9 b. du matin k 11 h. du soir. 11 nous serait agréable de voir les Sociétaires le fréquenter assidûment ; ils y trouveront d’ailleurs, eu dehors des jeux de toutes sortes, un bnffet qui ne livre que des consommations de premier ohoix.

De plus, nous portons k votre connaissance que, k partir du 24 courant, il y sera donné des santaries chaque dimanche, de 6 b. k 11 b. du soir, précédées de temps k antre d’uce petite séance. La sauterie du 24 courant sera précédée d’une petite séanœ artistique.

Noas ne saurions trop recommander anx Sociétaires d’emmener régulièrement leurs familles k ces sauteries, la parfaite courtoisie et le respect le plus absolu présidant rigoureusement anx récré irions intimes de l’U. A. F.
Nous profitons de la circonstance pour dis siper le malentendu qui s’est produit k l’Edeu le soir de notre représentation le 6 oourant.

Le Comité qni compte d’aillenrs dans son sein 6 Membres Etrangers, se fait un devoir de vous rappeler que si la Société porte le titre d’Union Artistique Française au lien d’Union Artistique Internationale, o’est paroe que d’après les Statuts son programme est français, la Société ayant été fondée dans le seul et nni que bat de donner aux étrangers la facilité de se familiariser aveo la laugne française.

Voilk pourquoi le Comité, souoieux des in. térêts qui lui sont oonfiés, fait tous ses efforts ponr amener, en dehors de la colonie française, les antres nationaux sans distinction d’origine k adhérer k notre programme.
La présence de oes derniers dans notre groupement noas est d'autant pins préciéase qu’elle nous permet de réaliser l’idéal des Fondateurs.
C’est ainsi, par exemple, qu’k la dernière soirée donnée k rEden, Bit 8 Amateurs ayant interprété on rôle, an seal était français.
En somme, sans les Etrangers notre Société n’aurait plus sa raison d’être.
Il résulte que si notre programme est français, la Sooiété est au fond Internationale.

Nous vous devions oes explioations et nous vous les donnons en conviant tous les Sooié taires k vivre en bonne harmonie, en frères, attendu que, par la concorde, notie Sooiété qni progresse chaqae joar, est appelée dans no avenir prochain k occuper nue belle place dans la ville d’Alexandrie.
Le Président, Justin Paul.

div.head: A Light Nourishment for General Use.
Allenburys' DIET
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & The aged.
Allen & Hanburys Ltd., Lombard St. London.

div.head: SANATORIA FOR WORKING MEN.
div.p: To the Editor op the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—I am desired by Her Royal Highness Princess Christian, President, and the Committee, to ask if you will be so kind as to insert the enclosed appeal, signed by Her Royal Highness, in your valuable columns.

You will see from a perusal of it that it is an essentially National movement, in which Princess Christian is taking an active and deep interest. She has promised to preside at an important meeting at the Memorial Hall, Farringdon Street, on November 18th, and is sending a personal invitation to the Mayors of the various towns of the United Kingdom to attend it

I also enclose for your perusal a reprint of the leading article which appeared in the London “Daily Telegraph” of June 26th last which deals with the subject in a very succinct form, and if yon can draw attention to the appeal in your editorial columns, my Committee would be very grateful.
I am, Faithfully yours, E. Douglas White.

p.hi: To the Editor op the Egyptian Gazette.

div.p: Sir,—An organisation has been formed to carry out the above-named important object. How important it is can best be realised by a consideration of statistics which Dr. Latham submitted at the last Annual Meeting of the Hospital Saturday Fund. He stated that in London alone 16,000 persons die every year whose valuable lives might be saved with proper treatment, to say nothing of the thousands who are slowly moving to their doom.

Again, taking London by itself, he computes that no less than 80,000 of its popu lation are stricken with one form or another of tuberculosis, and makes the startling deduction that one in every sixty-five will be dead in five years’ time from a preventable disease.

The monetary loss to the industrial classes is appalling, and though there are no actual figures to go by, some comparative idea can he formed by the estimate, which Dr. Herman Briggs, the well-known health officer of New York, calculates cost £66,000,000 annually to the United States.

Owing to the work of the Poor Law Unions and the few Consumption Hospitals and the National Association for the Prevention of Consumption, in which His Majesty the King takes a deep personal interest, the death rate from tuberculosis has been reduced during the last sixty years by no less than two-thirds, which means a saving of 75,000 lives a year.

The National Committee, of which Her Royal Highness Princess Christian is President has been established under the auspices of the Hospital Saturday Fund, for the establishment of Sanatoria for workers suffering from tuberculosis ; it is an exceptionally representative body, including delegates from practically all the great Friendly Societies and Trades Unions, and the work is receiving enthusiastic support in all directions.

The Special Appeal Committee consists of Her Royal Highness Princess Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, Her Highness Princess Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein. the Duchess of Somerset, the Marchioness of Londonderry, the Earl and Countess Cadogan, the Earl and Countess of Derby, the Bishop of Stepney, the Lady Brassey, the Lady St Heliers, the Hon. Harry Lawson and Mrs. Lawson, the Hon. Mrs. William West, Lady Duckworth, Sir William Taylor, Captain Balfour, M.P., and Lady Nina Balfour, Mr. Moore Bayley, Mr. Walter Burns, Mrs. James Coats, Mr. Eric Hambro, M.P., and Mrs. Eric Hambro, Mr. Charles and Mrs. Rube, and Mr. Van Alen, and it appeals to the public for £50,000 to provide the building and acquire the site for a first sanatorium for the accommodation of 200 patients. About £6,000 has already been promised, and a suitable site has been secured at Benenden, Kent.

The various Societies and Trades Unions guarantee the cost of maintenance, but under the terms of their constitution, they can only make small donations towards the building and purchase of land. The Sanatorium, therefore, will be self-supporting, and no appeal for funds will ever be made to the public again.
The following extract from Dr. Latham’s address is extremely interesting from the economic point of view : —

“Mr. Alfred Chapman and Mr. Russell, of " the Ancient Order of Foresters, have made " an important investigation into the cost of " consumption to a single Court of the Ancient " Order of Foresters. The result of this inves “ tigation is so striking that there is reason to " hopes that all the Friendly and Allied Socie-" ties will make exhaustive enquiries into the " subject. Mr. Russell finds that the average his Court is three times as great as the pay to any person dying from another disease. A man dying from consumption costs the Society £21, and a man dying from another disease costs £7.”

In pressing this appeal, enough has been said to bring home to the public the awful condition of things which this movement is organised to cope with ; no words are needed to make it more impressive—the pathos lies in the figures quoted above. In this sense it must appeal personally to every one, but it gains additional force, in that, it is economically sound and its working is based on the principles which govern the great industrial Benefit Societies, and applies the sound principle of thrift to the greatest of all blessings, health. It is is a practical movement against one of the worst scourges of our country, and in this sense becomes a truly national one.

The Special Appeal Committee earnestly invite employers of labour, Trades Unions and Friendly Societies who have not yet joined the movement, to do so. The Secretary, Mr. E. Douglas White, will be pleased to give fall particulars to any one applying to him.

Donors of £10 10s. and upwards will be entitled to have their names recorded as Founders of the Institution ; and donors of £250 and upwards, will, in addition, be entitled to name a bed. Donations should be sent to Mr. E. Douglas White, Secretary to the Special Appeal Fund, at the offices of the Committee, 19, South Molton Street, Bond Street, London. HELENA, President A. WILLIAM WEST, Treasure, 18, Lowndes Square, S.W. E. DOUGLAS WHITE, Secretary.

At Chelsea House to day, with the Princess Christian presiding, the preliminary steps will be taken by the National Committee for the Establishment of Sanatoria for Workers suffering from Tuberculosis towards bringing the project for which it was formed to wider public notice. The benefits of open-air treatment, especially in the earlier stages of this dire scourge, are now folly recognized, though unfortunately at present the means of cure are too limited, and many have to put up with inadequate and incomplete methods of treatment. This Committee, which has Princess Christian as its President, includes a very large number of well-known names in the list of its Vice-Presidents and active supporters, among them being the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Duke and Duchess of Portland, the Duke and Duchess of Westminster, Earl and Countess Cadogan, the Bishop of London, Lord Burnham, Sir Savile Crossley, Mr. A. J. Balfour, M.P., Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, M.P., Lord and Lady Cheylesmore, the Hon. Harry Lawson, M.P., and Mrs. Lawson, Lord and Lady Iveagh, the Chief Rabbi, Sir William Broadbent, and Mr. and Mrs. Leopold de Rothschild. The co-operation of the great Provident and Friendly Societies has been secured, as it is the primary aim of the effort to he entirely Self-supporting when once established. Hence upon the Committee are representatives of such well-reputed Societies as the Ancient Order of Foresters, the Independent Order of Foresters, the Independent Order of Oddfellows, the Hearts of Oak, the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants, the Fawcett Association (General Post Office), the Hospital Saturday Fund, the Board of Guardians for the Relief of the Jewish Poor, the London Society of Compositors, and many more.

The speakers at the meeting will include Earl Cadogan, the Bishop of Stepney, Dr. Acland, Mr. Garland (Chairman of the Committee), and Mr. Bunn (Secretary of the Hospital Saturday Fond). Details will then be given concerning the scheme, which, briefly, is to erect a first sanatorium for the accommodation of 200 patients. It is to be upon a scale simpler and less expensive than has yet been tried, and it is believed that many of those who seek its early aid will he not only capable of, but actually benefited by doing, light farm work, by which it will be made self-supporting. A most promising site has been secured at Benenden, in Kent, and the total estimated cost for its purchase and for putting up suitable premises is £50,000. After this, the various Societies co-operating will contribute towards the maintenance of their own exertions. About £2000 is already promised. According to present intentions, a monster mass meeting is to take place in the autumn to bring the project directly to the notice of working people.

On Thursday next, at Chelsea House, under the Presidency of her Royal Highness Princess Christian, with Lord Cadogan as Chairman, will be held a meeting to further a philanthropic movement of a novel and most promising character. The movement is novel in the sense that it combines two well-known principles, both of which flourish separately in this country, but which are rarely, if ever, found in combination. The object is primarily to fight the great White Plague - as Tuberculosis is grimly but appropriately called—as is done in many Institutions scattered over the country supported by voluntary contributions. What differentiates the aims of the “National Committee-for the Establishment of Sanatoria for Workers suffering from Tuberculosis” is this: After the initial expense—only some fifty thousand pounds—of acquiring land and erecting the necessary buildings has been raised by the liberality of the munificent, the whole main-tenance of the Institution will be paid for by the class for whose benefit it will exist, through the medium of the great Friendly Societies, Trade Unions and other cognate organizations. This is really a new departure, to which, perhaps, the nearest parallel is the Rowton Houses system. The effort is an economic as well as a charitable one, and as soon as the material fabric has been erected and paid for, the charitable will never be called upon to subscribe again. On the other hand, the self-respect of the working-classes will be maintained at a high level, because those who profit by the advantages offered to them will be conscious that they owe the opportunity, not to charity, but to their own qualities of thrift and providence. Most people are aware, in a general way, of the ravages of consumption and other forms of tuberculosis, but few realize how deadly and devastating this scourge is. For instance, how many who read this article grasp the awful truth that tuberculosis kills one victim in England and Wales every five minutes Every twenty-four honrs of the year, on an average day, there die two hundred and eighty-eight human beings in England and Wales of a disease which, in its earlier stages at least, is curable. This is no wild guesswork, but an inexorable conclusion drawn, as Dr La-thom told the Committee of the Hospital Saturday Fund at the annual meeting two months ego, from the unimpeachable statistics of the Registrar General. A death list such as this, from a colliery accident or a shipwreck, would occupy public attention for Weeks ; and yet, day in and day out, this curable disease carries off all but three hundred victims. Dr. Lathom farther tells us that in London alone we have to day forty thousand persons—the strength of an army corps—suffering from consumption and if we include all forms of tuberculosis, the total of the working-classes is double that of the population of London as a whole. And Dr. Lathom puts the case in this startling but too well confirmed form : “Of the working-class - men, women, and ohildren-whom yon meet in the streets of London to-day—at least one in thirty three will be dead within five years from taberculosis.” These are sober facts which may well stagger humanity.

It is not, of course, contended that treatment at the earliest appreciable stage of the disease in the best-equipped sanatoria will extinguish this colossal death-roll. Medical science, with its magnificent record of marvellous achievements to give it confidence. does anticipate that in time tuberculosis will be the name of an almost obsolete plague But physicians are certain-with a certainty born of actual experience-that a reduction of at least one-half, or even two-thirds, can be effected at a cost which would not only increase the liabilities of the great Friendly Societies, but would actually diminish them. Messrs. Russell and Chapman, who speak with the highest authority on the financial position of the Ancient Order of Free Forester, have given us the result of their investigation into the cost of consumption to a single Court of the Order. They say that “the average cost of sick pay to a consumptive member of this Court is three time as great as the pay to any person dying from another disease. A man dying from consumption costs the Society twenty-one pounds, and a man dying from an other disease costs seven pounds”

Nor is this all we have to go by Dr Lathom, and there is no more trustworthy authority, made the following statement to the Board of the Hospital Saturday Fund in the address from which we have already quoted— "As many of you are aware, a law was passed in Germany some years back which compelled every one with an income of less than one hundred pounds per annum to insure against for a few years the insurance companies were heavily hit by consumption, At least one person in every three who drew sick pay from them was suffering from tuberculosis. The companies investigated the matter thoroughly. They sought medical advice, and were told that the most hopeful treatment of consumption was by means of efficient sanatoria. They were, moreover, told that if no treatment were attempted, possibly two consumptives in every ten would be cured by natural means, but if patients were sent in a sufficiently early stage to sanatoria, seven out of ten would have the disease arrested. The chairman of one of the principal German insurance companies proved that if one hundred and forty-out of five hundred consumptives could be so far. restored to health as to do without sick pay for one year, this would be sufficient to recoup the company for their treatment in a sanatorium, or for the erection and maintenance of an institution of its own. Consequently, the German insurance companies erected sanatoria for their clients, and so satisfied are the business men with the results, that they are extending the system.”

Already the idea, which is the object of this meeting on Thursday to promote, has caught on with the leaders of the great Friendly Societies, Trade Unions and other similar organisations. Mr. Garland, who is well known as a representative of the Poet Office employees, has obtained the consent of the Postmaster-General to a reduction of two shillings a year from the pay of all employés willing to give their consent, and it is hoped that a sufficient sum will thus be raised to endow fifty beds for postmen, sorters, and other servants of the Poet Office.

Of course, it will at once be asked, why do not the Friendly Societies find the money for building sanatoria of their own t The answer is simple ; that, under the existing Friendly Societies Acts, the different Boards may not employ their accumulated funds in other than the strictly limited and scheduled way. But if this inexpensive experiment proves a success— as it is practically certain to do—the Friendly Societies will be stimulated to have the Acts controlling their employment of funds relaxed so as to enable them to build sanatoria for themselves, or to endow beds in existing institutions.

Our reason for calling attention to this meritorious scheme (details of which can be acquired by applying to the Secretary, at the Offices, 54. Gray’s Inn Road, W.C.) is that it seeks to cope with a terrible and increasing evil, by aid of remedies the efficacy of which has been demonstrated on a large scale, and on economic principles which must induce the working-man to protect himself, at a very slight cost, against a disease which is more than decimating the class of which he is a member.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
